static_1.label: static
values: {"display":"Quartile Distribution","chart":"hbar","value":"q = load \"simha__Wave_Sample_Opportunities3\";\nq = group q by 'Billing_Country';\n \nq = foreach q generate 'Billing_Country',\nsum('Amount') as 'sum_Revenue',\nrank() over ([..] partition by all order by sum('Amount')) as 'Position', sum(1) over ([..] partition by all) as 'count';\nq = foreach q generate 'Billing_Country',\n'sum_Revenue', ( case\nwhen 'Position' <= (floor(('count' + 1)/4)) then \"1st Quartile\" \nwhen 'Position' >= (floor(((3*'count') + 1)/4)) then \"4th Quartile\" \nwhen 'Position' <= (floor(((2*'count') + 1)/4)) then \"2nd Quartile\" \nelse \"3rd Quartile\" end ) as 'Quartile';\nq = group q by ('Billing_Country', 'Quartile');\nq = foreach q generate 'Quartile' as 'Quartile', 'Billing_Country' as 'Billing_Country', max('sum_Revenue') as 'sum_Revenue';\nq = order q by 'sum_Revenue' desc;"}

{"display":"Mean Distribution","chart":"combo","value":"q = load \"simha__Wave_Sample_Opportunities3\";\n\nq = filter q by date('Created_Date_Year', 'Created_Date_Month', 'Created_Date_Day') in [dateRange([2016,2,18], [2016,8,16])];\n\n\n\nq = group q by 'Industry';\nq=foreach q generate 'Industry',avg('Amount') as 'Amount' ,median(avg('Amount')) over ( [..] partition by all ) as\n'group_median' ;\nL = filter q by 'Amount' <= 'group_median';\nL = group L by 'Industry';\nL = foreach L generate 'Industry',avg('Amount') as 'Amount',\nmedian('Amount') as 'Lmedian',avg('group_median') as\n'group_median',median(avg('Amount')) over ( [..] partition by all ) as\n'Lgroup_median';\nH = filter q by 'Amount' > 'group_median';\nH = group H by 'Industry';\nH = foreach H generate 'Industry',avg('Amount') as\n'Amount',median('Amount') as 'Hmedian',avg('group_median') as\n'group_median',median(avg('Amount')) over ( [..] partition by all ) as\n'Hgroup_median';\nF = union L,H;\nF=group F by 'Industry';F=foreach F generate\n'Industry',avg('Amount') as 'Amount',avg(avg('group_median')) over (\n[..] partition by all ) as 'Median',avg(avg('Lgroup_median')) over ( [..]\npartition by all ) as 'Lower Group Median',avg(avg('Hgroup_median')) over ( [..]\npartition by all ) as 'Top Group Median';"}

parameters.text:
For a closer view of the distribution, we divide the average industry opportunity values up into groups, then look at the medians for each group. More medians, more insight.

Sounds like a lot of steps, but now we can see that our top group is more spread out than our bottom group. This is good to know!

Want to learn more about the Quartiles example? Check out the Quartiles section of the app!
Load the dataset and filter by date range.
Want to see how your data is distributed? It could be spread out evenly, or it could be clustered.  SAQL data spreads provide key information about your data!

In this example, we can look at distribution across quartiles. We can also compare how the median of our highest values compares to the median of our lowest. Slice and dice.

Understanding the spread of your data can be valuable for a variety of use cases, such as opportunities won or lost, individual or team performance, or products sold.
If you're concerned about consistency in your data, understanding spread is critical! Toggle between charts to see different ways to uncover how the values in your dataset are distributed.

F = union L,H;
F=group F by 'Industry';F=foreach F generate\n'Industry',avg('Amount') as 'Amount',avg(avg('group_median')) over ([..] partition by all ) as 'Median',avg(avg('Lgroup_median')) over ( [..]partition by all ) as 'Lower Group Median',avg(avg('Hgroup_median')) over ( [..]partition by all ) as 'Top Group Median';

Data spreads help clarify what's going on in your dataset. Most of us are familiar with modes, medians, and means, but these only tell a small part of the story, especially when your dataset is large. 

Measures of spread can take your understanding to the next level by showing how scattered or concentrated values are and how much they differ from the mean.
Group by Industry and calculate the average opportunity amount. Then calculate the median of the averages and chart that red line.

q = group q by 'Industry';
q=foreach q generate 'Industry',avg('Amount') as 'Amount' ,median(avg('Amount')) over ( [..] partition by all ) as 'group_median' ;
Upper Group: Filter for industries above the median to calculate the mediad for the upper group (green).
Here, we union the lower and upper streams and add labels.

q = load \"Wave_Sample_Opportunities\";
q = filter q by date('Created_Date_Year', 'Created_Date_Month', 'Created_Date_Day') in [dateRange([2016,2,18], [2016,8,16])];
Lower Group: Filter for industries with average opportunity sizes below the median. Then calculate the median of the lower group (yellow).
